trans-unit.source: Get started configuring an internet facing load balancer using Azure Resource Manager | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get started configuring an internet facing load balancer using Azure Resource Manager | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: How to create a load balancer rules, NAT rules, probe for Azure Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: How to create a load balancer rules, NAT rules, probe for Azure Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: Step by step showing end to end process to create a load balancer resource.
trans-unit.target: Step by step showing end to end process to create a load balancer resource.

trans-unit.source: Get started configuring an internet facing load balancer using Azure Resource Manager
trans-unit.target: Get started configuring an internet facing load balancer using Azure Resource Manager

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.SELECTOR]
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.SELECTOR]

trans-unit.source: Azure Classic steps
trans-unit.target: Azure Classic steps

trans-unit.source: Resource Manager Powershell steps
trans-unit.target: Resource Manager Powershell steps

trans-unit.source: The steps below will show how to create an internet facing load balancer using Azure Resource Manager with PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: The steps below will show how to create an internet facing load balancer using Azure Resource Manager with PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: With Azure Resource Manager, the items to create an internet facing load balancer are configured individually and then put together to create a resource.
trans-unit.target: With Azure Resource Manager, the items to create an internet facing load balancer are configured individually and then put together to create a resource.

trans-unit.source: We will cover in this page the sequence of individual tasks it has to be done to create a load balancer and explain in detail what is being done to accomplish the goal to create a load balancer.
trans-unit.target: We will cover in this page the sequence of individual tasks it has to be done to create a load balancer and explain in detail what is being done to accomplish the goal to create a load balancer.

trans-unit.source: What is required to create an internet facing load balancer?
trans-unit.target: What is required to create an internet facing load balancer?

trans-unit.source: The following items need to be configured before creating a load balancer:
trans-unit.target: The following items need to be configured before creating a load balancer:

trans-unit.source: Front end IP configuration - will add a public IP address to front end IP pool for incoming network traffic to load balance.
trans-unit.target: Front end IP configuration - will add a public IP address to front end IP pool for incoming network traffic to load balance.

trans-unit.source: Backend address pool - will configure the network interfaces which will receive the load balanced traffic coming from front end IP pool.
trans-unit.target: Backend address pool - will configure the network interfaces which will receive the load balanced traffic coming from front end IP pool.

trans-unit.source: Load balancing rules - source and local port configuration for the load balancer.
trans-unit.target: Load balancing rules - source and local port configuration for the load balancer.

trans-unit.source: Probes - configures the health status probe for the Virtual Machine instances.
trans-unit.target: Probes - configures the health status probe for the Virtual Machine instances.

trans-unit.source: Inbound NAT rules - configures the port rules to directly access one of the Virtual Machine instances.
trans-unit.target: Inbound NAT rules - configures the port rules to directly access one of the Virtual Machine instances.

trans-unit.source: You can get more information about load balancer components with Azure resource manager at [Azure Resource Manager support for load balancer](load-balancer-arm.md).
trans-unit.target: You can get more information about load balancer components with Azure resource manager at [Azure Resource Manager support for load balancer](load-balancer-arm.md).

trans-unit.source: The following steps will show how to configure a load balancer to be load balanced between 2 virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: The following steps will show how to configure a load balancer to be load balanced between 2 virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: Step by Step using powershell
trans-unit.target: Step by Step using powershell

trans-unit.source: Create Resource Group for load balancer
trans-unit.target: Create Resource Group for load balancer

trans-unit.source: Step 1
trans-unit.target: Step 1

trans-unit.source: Make sure you switch PowerShell mode to use the ARM cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you switch PowerShell mode to use the ARM cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: More info is available at Using [Windows Powershell with Resource Manager](powershell-azure-resource-manager.md).
trans-unit.target: More info is available at Using [Windows Powershell with Resource Manager](powershell-azure-resource-manager.md).

trans-unit.source: Step 2
trans-unit.target: Step 2

trans-unit.source: Log in to your Azure account.
trans-unit.target: Log in to your Azure account.

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to Authenticate with your credentials.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to Authenticate with your credentials.

trans-unit.source: Step 3
trans-unit.target: Step 3

trans-unit.source: Choose which of your Azure subscriptions to use.
trans-unit.target: Choose which of your Azure subscriptions to use.

trans-unit.source: To see a list of available subscriptions, use the ‘Get-AzureSubscription’ cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To see a list of available subscriptions, use the ‘Get-AzureSubscription’ cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Step 4
trans-unit.target: Step 4

trans-unit.source: Create a new resource group (skip this step if using an existing resource group)
trans-unit.target: Create a new resource group (skip this step if using an existing resource group)

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Manager requires that all resource groups specify a location.
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Manager requires that all resource groups specify a location.

trans-unit.source: This is used as the default location for resources in that resource group.
trans-unit.target: This is used as the default location for resources in that resource group.

trans-unit.source: Make sure all commands to create a load balancer will use the same resource group.
trans-unit.target: Make sure all commands to create a load balancer will use the same resource group.

trans-unit.source: In the example above we created a resource group called "NRP-RG" and location "West US".
trans-unit.target: In the example above we created a resource group called "NRP-RG" and location "West US".

trans-unit.source: Create Virtual Network and a public IP address for front end IP pool
trans-unit.target: Create Virtual Network and a public IP address for front end IP pool

trans-unit.source: Step 1
trans-unit.target: Step 1

trans-unit.source: Create a virtual network:
trans-unit.target: Create a virtual network:

trans-unit.source: Creates a subnet for the virtual network and assigns to $backendSubnet
trans-unit.target: Creates a subnet for the virtual network and assigns to $backendSubnet

trans-unit.source: Creates the virtual network and adds the subnet lb-subnet-be to the virtual network NRPVNet.
trans-unit.target: Creates the virtual network and adds the subnet lb-subnet-be to the virtual network NRPVNet.

trans-unit.source: Step 2
trans-unit.target: Step 2

trans-unit.source: Create a public IP address to be used by frontend IP pool:
trans-unit.target: Create a public IP address to be used by frontend IP pool:

trans-unit.source: Create Front end IP pool and backend address pool
trans-unit.target: Create Front end IP pool and backend address pool

trans-unit.source: Setting up a front end IP pool for the incoming load balancer network traffic and backend address pool to receive the load balanced traffic.
trans-unit.target: Setting up a front end IP pool for the incoming load balancer network traffic and backend address pool to receive the load balanced traffic.

trans-unit.source: Step 1
trans-unit.target: Step 1

trans-unit.source: Using public IP variable ($publicIP), create the front end IP pool.
trans-unit.target: Using public IP variable ($publicIP), create the front end IP pool.

trans-unit.source: step 2
trans-unit.target: step 2

trans-unit.source: Set up a back end address pool used to receive incoming traffic from front end IP pool:
trans-unit.target: Set up a back end address pool used to receive incoming traffic from front end IP pool:

trans-unit.source: Create LB rules, NAT rules, probe and load balancer
trans-unit.target: Create LB rules, NAT rules, probe and load balancer

trans-unit.source: After creating the front end IP pool and the backend address pool, you will need to create the rules which will belong to the load balancer resource:
trans-unit.target: After creating the front end IP pool and the backend address pool, you will need to create the rules which will belong to the load balancer resource:

trans-unit.source: Step 1
trans-unit.target: Step 1

trans-unit.source: The example above is creating the following items:
trans-unit.target: The example above is creating the following items:

trans-unit.source: NAT rule which all incoming traffic to port 3441 will go to port 3389.
trans-unit.target: NAT rule which all incoming traffic to port 3441 will go to port 3389.

trans-unit.source: a second NAT rule which all incoming traffic to port 3442 will go to port 3389.
trans-unit.target: a second NAT rule which all incoming traffic to port 3442 will go to port 3389.

trans-unit.source: a load balancer rule which will load balance all incoming traffic on public port 80 to local port 80 in the back end address pool.
trans-unit.target: a load balancer rule which will load balance all incoming traffic on public port 80 to local port 80 in the back end address pool.

trans-unit.source: a probe rule which will check the health status for path "HealthProbe.aspx"
trans-unit.target: a probe rule which will check the health status for path "HealthProbe.aspx"

trans-unit.source: Step 2
trans-unit.target: Step 2

trans-unit.source: Create the load balancer adding all objects (NAT rules, Load balancer rules, probe configurations) together:
trans-unit.target: Create the load balancer adding all objects (NAT rules, Load balancer rules, probe configurations) together:

trans-unit.source: Create network interfaces
trans-unit.target: Create network interfaces

trans-unit.source: After creating the load balancer, you need define which network interfaces will be receiving the incoming load balanced network traffic, NAT rules and probe.
trans-unit.target: After creating the load balancer, you need define which network interfaces will be receiving the incoming load balanced network traffic, NAT rules and probe.

trans-unit.source: The network interface in this case is configured individually and can be assigned to a virtual machine later on.
trans-unit.target: The network interface in this case is configured individually and can be assigned to a virtual machine later on.

trans-unit.source: Step 1
trans-unit.target: Step 1

trans-unit.source: Get the resource virtual network and subnet to create network interfaces:
trans-unit.target: Get the resource virtual network and subnet to create network interfaces:

trans-unit.source: In this step, we are creating a network interface which will belong to the load balancer back end pool and associate the first NAT rule for RDP for this network interface:
trans-unit.target: In this step, we are creating a network interface which will belong to the load balancer back end pool and associate the first NAT rule for RDP for this network interface:

trans-unit.source: Step 2
trans-unit.target: Step 2

trans-unit.source: Create a second network interface called LB-Nic2-BE:
trans-unit.target: Create a second network interface called LB-Nic2-BE:

trans-unit.source: In this step, we are creating a second network interface, assigning to the same load balancer back end pool and associating the second NAT rule created for RDP:
trans-unit.target: In this step, we are creating a second network interface, assigning to the same load balancer back end pool and associating the second NAT rule created for RDP:

trans-unit.source: The end result will show the following:
trans-unit.target: The end result will show the following:

trans-unit.source: PS C:\> $backendnic1
trans-unit.target: PS C:\> $backendnic1

trans-unit.source: Step 3
trans-unit.target: Step 3

trans-unit.source: Use the command Add-AzureVMNetworkInterface to assign the NIC to a virtual Machine.
trans-unit.target: Use the command Add-AzureVMNetworkInterface to assign the NIC to a virtual Machine.

trans-unit.source: You can find the step by step to create a virtual machine and assign to a NIC following the documentation [Create and preconfigure a Windows Virtual Machine with Resource Manager and Azure PowerShell](virtual-machines-ps-create-preconfigure-windows-resource-manager-vms.md#Example)
trans-unit.target: You can find the step by step to create a virtual machine and assign to a NIC following the documentation [Create and preconfigure a Windows Virtual Machine with Resource Manager and Azure PowerShell](virtual-machines-ps-create-preconfigure-windows-resource-manager-vms.md#Example)
